Expectation1: Prepare and maintain financial records accurately.
Situation1: It's time for the routine quarterly filing of internal financial documents.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: An official explains that, because of a registration mismatch, the voter must complete a provisional ballot form before the station closes in ten minutes.
Story:
I sat at my desk, calculator in hand, double-checking the quarterly financial records. The deadline for filing was tonight, and I knew every number had to be perfect—my job depended on it. Just as I was about to finalize the last spreadsheet, my phone buzzed with a reminder: today was election day. I’d promised myself I’d vote, no matter how busy work got. 

I rushed to the polling station, only to be told by an official that my registration had a mismatch. If I wanted my vote to count, I had to fill out a provisional ballot form before the station closed—in just ten minutes. My mind raced. If I stayed, I’d risk missing the filing deadline and jeopardizing my professional integrity. If I left, I’d forfeit my right to vote, something I believed in deeply. The weight of both roles pressed down on me, each demanding my full attention, each unwilling to wait. My heart pounded as I stood frozen, torn between duty to my profession and duty to my democracy.
